explanation: To decide whether this function uses compiler language extensions you must inspect all macros, typedefs and any called inline/macros used directly in the body (these are the usual places extensions appear). - OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This macro is the most likely place for GNU/C extensions (statement-expressions, typeof, __extension__, inline asm, etc.). Inspect its definition. - OS_impl_task_table: The macro is invoked with this symbol; its type/definition may influence how the macro expands and whether extensions are used. - OS_object_token_t: The function parameter type; its declaration could use compiler extensions (e.g. anonymous structs/unions, attributes, typeof, flexible array usage). - OS_impl_task_internal_record_t: The type of 'impl'; its definition is needed to check for extension use and to confirm the type of the 'id' member. - OS_ObjectIdFromToken: This helper is called inside the debug call; it may be a macro or inline that uses extensions. - OS_ObjectIdToInteger: Same reason as above — could be a macro/inline using extensions or type punning. - OS_DEBUG: Typically a macro; must be inspected for variadic macro usage, GNU extensions in its expansion (statement-expr, nested macros using typeof, etc.). - int32: The integer typedef used as the function return type; its definition may use compiler-specific typedefs or attributes. - OS_ERROR and OS_SUCCESS: These constants/macros may be defined using compiler extensions (e.g. enum with attributes, macros using typeof). - pthread_detach and pthread_t: pthread_detach is an external API but pthread_t typedef/implementation could be compiler/system specific (e.g. union/struct, attributes); inspect only if typedef forms could involve extensions. - strerror: Standard library function; include for completeness to ensure no wrapped macro/extension is used. Inspecting these symbols lets the next analyst determine whether any part of the expanded code or type definitions relies on compiler-specific language extensions that would violate the MISRA rule.
